definition[0]: to catch a person and keep them as a prisoner
example[0]: Government troops have succeeded in capturing the rebel leader.
definition[1]: to get control of a place or object that previously belonged to an enemy, during a war
example[2]: The town was captured after a siege lasting ten days.
example[3]: The Dutch fleet captured two English ships.
definition[2]: to catch an animal after chasing or following it
example[4]: The tiger was finally captured two miles outside the village.
definition[3]: to succeed in recording, showing, or describing a situation or feeling, using words or pictures
example[5]: These photographs capture the essence of working-class life at the turn of the century.
example[6]: The robbery was captured on police video cameras.
definition[4]: to get something that previously belonged to one of your competitors
example[7]: We aim to capture eight percent of the UK wine market.
example[8]: Republicans captured three Senate seats from the Democrats.
definition[5]: to put something in a form that a computer can use
example[9]: The data is captured by an optical scanner.
definition[6]: to remove one of your opponentâ€™s pieces from the board in chess
definition[7]: when you catch someone in order to make them a prisoner
example[10]: The two soldiers somehow managed to avoid capture.
definition[8]: when soldiers get control of a place that previously belonged to an enemy
definition[9]: when you get control of something that previously belonged to one of your competitors
definition[10]: when you put information into a form a computer can use
example[12]: Japanese firms have captured over 60% of the electronics market.
definition[11]: to put something such as information or a picture into a form that a computer can use
example[13]: The data is captured using an optical scanner.
